item.desc: Aläqa Tayye (also spelled Taye) Gabra Maryam (1858–1924) was an Ethiopian scholar and teacher. He wrote five books, among them a Geez Grammar (published by the Swedish Mission at Minkwillo, Eritrea, in 1897). He was a preacher in Monkolu for about 20 years and drew the attention of Emperor Menilek II who commissioned him to write a history of Ethiopia. But the Emperor also had to protect Tayye from the clergy of the church, many of whom considered Tayye a heretic. Around 1905, Menilek sent Tayye to Germany for four years at the request of Kaiser Wilhelm II who had asked for a scholar who could catalogue Ethiopian manuscripts and teach Gǝ‘ǝz. He worked with Germany’s Dr. Eugene Mittwoch to publish a set of Ethiopian folk songs in 1907. After Menilek’s decline he was imprisoned, but eventually reinstated as a scholar and published a social history of Ethiopia in 1922. The entry in the list of biographies, ብላቴን፡ ጌታ፡ ማኅተመ፡ ሥላሴ፡ ወልደ፡ መስቀል፡ ቼ፡ በለው፡, says this about Aleqa Tayye: “Native of Bägemdǝr. In addition to mastering our country’s church education, he was educated abroad. He expended great energy in order to write down the entire history of Ethiopia and produced many books. In order to acknowledge his learning and to say, “He knows; Let him speak; Let him tell the story; Let him present the argument,” he was named “Abba Yǝbäl” [which means Knowledgeable Father]. Aleqa Tayye was praised for his scholarship and his work became his memorial in history.”
The manuscript is written in black and red ink on lined paper, held in a two-ring binder. After three pages of front matter, the main work begins and the pages are numbered throughout in Amharic

Yellow card with the following typewritten in red ink: “This manuscript belongs to Dr. F. B. Hylander and is deposited with Yemissrach Dimts Literature Programme. It is to be returned to Rev. M. Lundgren, Mekane Yesus Church Headquarters. Tel. 17220.”
